Entries.default: Shaking his head, Tekēhu seems uncertain of where to place his focus. He draws and expels heavy, whistling breaths through his nose.
You catch Tekēhu glancing your way. He quickly focuses elsewhere and smooths back his hair when he notices your attention.
"Something on your mind?"
"Is there anything the Watcher does not see?" Tekēhu grins, but the look quickly diminishes.
"What is it now?"
"My apologies, I... have trouble ordering the ideas in my head."
"Do you want to talk?"

"To my tribe, the watershapers were keepers of the past. Our connection to the ancestors."

His speech rises in intensity, though he doesn't seem aware of it.
"How the guild heaped praise on Ngati's chosen. How they congratulated themselves for acquiring me, I say."
"My cage was a gilded one. Their dragon... he was not so lucky."
"I see your point. They used you both."
"You don't think you're blowing this just a little out of proportion?"
[Say nothing.]
He folds his arms and glowers at you.
"The guild teaches a likeness of Ngati's art. For shame! But they posture before outsiders like masters of old!" He holds up an authoritative finger, breathing heavily.
"The guild doesn't deserve you."
"Watershaping keeps the peace no matter how it changed over the years."
"The guild needs you more than you need them. Go your own way."
"Neketaka needs your strength. See that the guild remembers that."

"Captain, you have let the handsome fish do all the talking. I needed this. Thank you." 

He releases a heavy sigh, shaking out his arms as the tension dissipates.
"I like hearing the handsome fish talk."
"It's no problem, Tekēhu."
"Keep whining and I'll throw you back into the pond where I caught you."
One of Tekēhu's hairs slips over his ear. He smooths it back with a gentle squish, clearing his throat.
"Ekera, let us be off."
"Aha. Noted." He raises his brow, shrugging.
"Between the crown and the guild, Neketaka has high hopes for Ngati's chosen son, I say." Tekēhu smooths back his hair with both hands as he gathers his thoughts.
"I say there is me, Tekēhu, and there is the Tekēhu others would make like a coconut husk doll."
"Delver's Row will take care of them for a time, but I say the crown will not suffer the Príncipi for long."
"Without Delver's Row, Onekaza must work harder to deserve the trust of the Roparu."

"We have both seen the worst of the city. How the Roparu cluster like sea rats..." 

Tekēhu's hand unconsciously strays toward his stomach.
"I'd start with what you have and find a better system."
"I'd collaborate on a new plan for the city."
"I would let people organize their lives as they saw fit."
"I'd stay out of it - fix nothing, break nothing."
"How did the stone walls and paved lanes of Neketaka divide us so?" He sighs, shaking his head.
"You have walked the length of Neketaka's spine. How would you serve the needs of all these people at once?"
"Ekera, a practical solution. And one open to change."
"You think that something in the great pattern of Neketaka does not align with the Huana way?"
"I was hard pressed to find insight like yours in Periki's Overlook." Some of the tension leaves Tekēhu's shoulders, and he stands a little taller than before.
"I have more questions for you."
"Let's be off."

Nodding, Tekēhu absently tugs one of his hairs. For the moment he seems totally withdrawn. 

Finally he snaps back into focus, regarding you with a smile which seems both genuine and strained.
"You give too much power to the expectations of others."
"Others want to stoke your potential. No harm in that."
"No one should pressure you to be something you're not."
"But it is the adoring people who made Tekēhu the savior of the tribes." He shrugs, sighing.
"They sit me on the pedestal and observe, then when I make a move they say 'not so fast!'"
"Many think that I have a duty to the Huana. I say... I am the only one unconvinced."
"You're being strangely dismissive of your worth."
"The Huana need someone like you to unite the tribes."
"No one stands in your way but you."
Hesitating at first, Tekēhu envelops your hand into his - the scales along his palm both prickly and warm. Just as it seems he will break away, instead he leans in closer.
"I only dismiss what others would make of me. Ekera, I... I know what I am."

"Rubbish, I say. Heroes are made for tragic ends and handsome corpses."

In spite of his words, there's a gleam of quiet curiosity in his wandering gaze.

"I thought Eothas was too busy kicking over islands to blunt his teeth with mortals."

Tekēhu scrutinizes you with an unreadable expression.
"What say? You must take something from all this idle chatter with the gods."
"Eothas was more curious about me than I was about him."
"I don't wish to discuss it."
"For what does he listen to you, then? The gods I know are tight of lip and hard of hearing."
"He's searching his feelings and needed a mortal perspective."
"He might be worried about how we interpret his actions."
"I don't pretend to understand the motivations of a god."
"Then that is how it will be." Nodding agreeably, Tekēhu gestures ahead.
"I could not imagine the inner workings of a god." He trails off, looking away.
"He has inhabited a giant body and drained the souls of thousands - can he be anything but committed?" Tekēhu frowns.
"Ekera. It makes my head hurt whenever I try to figure out what Ngati wants from me."

"At least Eothas has you to keep him in check. What happens when we catch up to him is... something for future Tekēhu to worry about." 

He smiles wanly.
"I had some questions."
"Let's be off."
"They have a plan for us. The last thing they need is doubt."
"Better that they let us figure it out for ourselves."
"I've felt that weight of authority before. I have no desire to feel it again."
As he weighs your words, Tekēhu winces a little.
"Ukaizo... we are actually going to Ukaizo." Tekēhu turns his colorless gaze toward you - unfocused, but full of concern.
"How about what you want?"
"I'm more interested in catching up to Eothas."

"None of this changes how I feel when I practice the Forms... like swimming over an ocean trench, I say." 

He crosses his arms over his chest and sighs.

"The ancestors gave her unwavering devotion, and she gave them a gift." 

Tekēhu sighs and lazily scoops a palmful of water droplets from the air. They form a rough approximation of an angler fish.
"I gather my thoughts, captain. You are not ignored."
"You whine about the guild's honorifics, but you were complicit in them."
"When the guild and the crown say what is right, who would not doubt themselves first?"
"The guild must change for the Huana to grow. I say that is Ngati's message delivered through her son's mouth."
"The tribes have never needed Ukaizo more. With Ngati's blessing, I would bring Ukaizo to them."
"The tribes will look to ME to bridge our past and our future. A... heavy responsibility, I say."
"What would you expect to find on Ukaizo?"
"Tell me what you know of Ukaizo."
"So you're committed to finding the island."
"The bleached bones of the past? Lewd sculptures?"
"An island, a city, a dream. The best of our people before cataclysm buried it under ash and waves."
"Others call it the heart of the Huana empire. More still call it home."
"No one knows what the Huana left behind, and there is little enough for us to guess by."

"Whatever we find, what better crew than friends to find lost Ukaizo on treacherous seas, ekera?" 

He makes a sweeping gesture, grinning all the while.
"Glad we got him excited. Makes me wish I knew how to sail."

"Or we could visit the bathhouse for a nice, quiet soak. 

"Just a thought." He shrugs.
Pallegina smiles weakly as she gives Tekēhu a halfhearted nod and a shrug.
"Sounds... fun. Ekera. Right, Ishi?"
"Did you hear that? We're friends - him and I." She flushes prettily, a happy smile tugging at her lips.

"If you be taking requests, a few more beautiful lads and lasses wouldn't hurt none - provided they possessed a basic knowhow of knots, navigation, cannon powder, and such."

Serafen counts off the qualifications on his fingers.
"Ekera, how refreshing to know your course. One day for me, perhaps."

"I was the toast of Neketaka. 

"But all of that is behind me. I must turn away from delights and think of the tribes."
"And I am no one's savior! It is not for an artist to save the tribes, I say. To work miracles."
"I would discover what our ancestors forgot. The covenant is more important than ever."
"Learn what you can from Ukaizo, but let the tribes find their own way."
"Ukaizo belongs to all the people of the Deadfire. You have a duty to serve them."
"I want the tribes to grow on their own. My people deserve better than the promises of a handsome fish and his goddess mother."
"I will give it thought. There is time enough for that, at least." He nods, weighing your words with care.

"Ukaizo should be the discovery of our lifetime. With the trading companies and the Príncipi ready to descend on each other, I wish the island had kept its secrets a while longer." He lets out a weary sigh.
"Ngati gave you watershaping?"

"Ekera. Talent like mine was once effortless, I say. Our birthright as Huana." 

He smooths back his hair, his hands coming away damp.
"Our ancestors could raise islands or divide the seas. No warship could stand against us."

"Now only a fraction of us remember."

He wipes his palm dry, frowning all the while.

"The more I try to be the Tekēhu I know I am, the harder I am constrained! What say?" 

He brings up his gaze to meet yours.
"I... know how I seem. We did not have this word, 'conceited,' before Aedyrans landed on the isles."
"Poor thing - exhausted by all the free admiration?"
"You give people hope, Tekēhu."
"Everyone is welcome to achieve! I do not hoard success for myself."
"If people need hope, they should pray harder, or look to their own grindstone!"
"If Ngati had not 'blessed' me, I..."

"If Ngati had not touched me, I... I wonder if anyone would care." 

Tekēhu seems ready to say more. He stops himself and releases you from his grip.
"I say the goddess touched me for more than enriching one tribe, glorifying one island." Tekēhu bites his thumbnail and sighs.
"Everyone feels underappreciated from time to time."
"Well, I am not everyone. Ekera, I am the only watershaper with an ounce of originality!"
He gives you an annoyed look, holding it there for longer than necessary, before tossing his hair with a gentle squish.
"The guild and the tribes heaped prestige on you. They deserve something back."
"Ekera, but how can I accept such a debt? When will I know it is fulfilled?"
"I don't know if an enslaved dragon is an equal comparison."
"Captain, we are talking about me. There are no small comparisons to be made."
"But Periki twisted my art into a perversion. An echo of what it should be."
"What do you plan on doing about it?"
"The trading companies will recognize this weakness eventually."

"I will bring a change not seen since the days of our ancestors." 

Tekēhu thumbs his chin, considering.
"Ekera, and by then it will be too late."
"Nothing new. I've been at this before."
"And you knew things he did not? Ah." Tekēhu bites his thumbnail.
"This was the zenith of my ambitions."
"But then, I am not meant to. It is for mortals to flail in the darkness, I say, while gods point us toward light."
"Someone needs the power to shape our future."
"This should empower you, not paralyze you."

"The praise they showered on Ngati's chosen... until now, it all seemed an empty gesture.

"Never a promise that I could fulfill."
"You're too quick to cave to pressure."
"To serve my people is to betray myself as an artist. Perhaps I am no savior."
"The future of the Huana is in Mataru hands. Have faith in that."
"The tribes are unified but vulnerable. Ukaizo could make them strong again."
The world around you darkens, and once again you feel an insistent tug for your attention - the pull centering from Tekēhu's soul.
[Surrender to the sensation.]
[Repress the sensation.]
<ispeech>It pains me to see my boy so conflicted. Questions tear at his heart, and the ache reaches me even here.</ispeech> Ondra props her jaw on her fist and regards you coolly.

<ispeech>If you continue to encourage him, his life will grow more complicated. He will be the savior his people want - someone to drag their past into the present.</ispeech> She shrugs as if the distinction is nothing to her.
<ispeech>He so longs for his independence, but his people will not relinquish his destiny without a fight.</ispeech> Her lips part with a secret smile.

<ispeech>Empires have fallen since I favored the Huana with power and wisdom. How they wield it is their choice. Just see that my boy comes to no harm.</ispeech>

Before you have a chance to react, Ondra claps her hands - and your surroundings assert themselves once more.
"There is much to consider, and little time to decide our course. I fear that we will see the path before us before we are ready to walk it."

"Ukaizo will show us the way. The tribes will find themselves again."

He touches the spot on his forehead, his gaze unfocused with a momentary sense of awe.
"What do I want?" Tekēhu looks down, repeating the question under his breath.
The world around you darkens, and once again you feel an insistent tug for your attention - the pull centering from Tekēhu's soul.
[Surrender to the sensation.]
[Repress the sensation.]
The world reasserts itself all around you. Tekēhu wears an uncertain smile, tipping his head inquisitively.

<ispeech>Scratch under the wet clay of any artist and you hatch a lifetime of fear and doubt.</ispeech> 

Ondra props her chin on her fist and studies Tekēhu with a sigh.

<ispeech>Poor thing. Nothing he does could disappoint me, but that is a mother's prerogative.</ispeech>

She pulls away with a wet, slapping sound. You receive the mental impression of a wink.
The world around you darkens, and once again you feel an insistent tug for your attention - the pull centering from Tekēhu's soul.
[Surrender to the sensation.]
[Repress the sensation.]

<ispeech>My 'handsome fish' is intimidated by his own potential. How upsetting for him.</ispeech>

The air around you feels thick with moisture. Ondra leans forward in her throne.
<ispeech>See the anxiety that takes shelter behind his confident smile? He has worn that since he was old enough to crawl.</ispeech>

<ispeech>Help him to rise up from crawling. Help him to stand and walk as a man, as a god.</ispeech>

Her presence draws away, and watery fingers lightly brush the nape of your neck.
"Still with us, captain? I had no desire to bore you with my inane chatter." Tekēhu smirks, eyeing you with concern.

<ispeech>I could always plant the covenant in his dreams... but that would spoil the fun of Ukaizo.

My final test for the Huana.</ispeech>
The world around you darkens, and once again you feel an insistent tug for your attention - the pull centering from Tekēhu's soul.
[Surrender to the sensation.]
[Repress the sensation.]
<ispeech>Poor boy... he has it backward, as usual.</ispeech> A silky, distant voice asserts itself in your thoughts.

<ispeech>I did not choose him so that he could do great things. I chose him because talent should be fostered toward any end.</ispeech> Sadness and regret creep into her tone, but something about them rings falsely to your ears.
<ispeech>How fortunate that you are here to set him on the right path. I know you won't disappoint.</ispeech> You hear a smile in her words.

"Ah... apologies. I say I never miss an opportunity to talk about myself." 

The presence withdraws, leaving you unsteady on your feet. Oblivious, Tekēhu offers a broad, showy smile.
"I can tell you don't want to be anyone's savior."
"Ekera, yes." Tekēhu draws in a deep breath and nods, savoring your words.
He turns to face his surroundings, struggling to take in everything at once.
"The land of my mothers, as real as anything that rises up from the bed of the sea. Also, smaller than I expected." He lets out an exhausted laugh.
"Come, captain! We have not a moment to lose." Grinning, Tekēhu beckons you forward.
"I am thinking that Eothas has come this far, and he will not wait on you before he finishes what he started." Tekēhu regards you with a raised brow and a cautious smile.
"This should be as interesting as the last time I confronted a god-possessed adra colossus." Shrugging, Tekēhu gestures ahead.
"I will make sure that what we find here goes toward the Huana cause. The crown's faith in Ngati's chosen will be justified." He nods, resolute and ready.
"The Huana could use a change, an upset - something that gets them working together. History has shown that we thrive in adversity."
"If he shatters what has sat in the heart of Ukaizo, this action will ripple beyond the Deadfire. Beyond life as we know it."

<ispeech>My boy doesn't fear the gods. He only fears what he'll compromise by living up to his potential.

But isn't it easier to let sculptures represent you?</ispeech>

As you turn to Tekēhu, a shadow passes over your vision. You feel a tug from somewhere deep within his soul. 

A faint ripple creases the air between you two like a forest of ethereal kelp.
[Surrender to the sensation.]
Tekēhu's soul is vibrant and energetic - almost too lively to occupy its mortal shell. There is a bright thread of energy that trails away from him. You instinctively follow it.

<ispeech>A life without friction or challenge has left the boy in need of guidance.</ispeech> 

The voice of Ondra pounds at your mind with relentless force.

<ispeech>He thinks himself frail, but MY heart beats in his chest. He is stronger than either of you could know.</ispeech>

She claps her hands, and the vision shatters - flooding the hall with a deluge of awareness as you return to your senses.
[Repress the sensation.]

<ispeech>Not feeling talkative, are we? Know that I will be watching.</ispeech>

The voice pulls away from your mind with a wet, splashing sound.
Regarding you with a warm smile, Tekēhu at first seems oblivious to your momentary detachment. Then his brow furrows with concern.
"Captain what say? You look a little blue about the gills."
"I'm... fine. I had some questions."
"Let's be off."
"Ondra just reached out to me..."
"To inspire the world with Ngati's gift... this is my calling."

You stand in a grand hall, underwater and cloaked in oppressive shadows. 

Pillars of coral and bone reach up to support a ceiling that must be hundreds of fathoms away. Chandeliers lit with bioluminescent globes dangle from long ropes, swaying in languid, tentacular motions.

At the farthest end of the hall sits Ondra, as tall as a castle keep and leaning forward in her throne. She has adopted the head of an angler fish, and regards you with its globular stare. 

Her sickle-shaped jaw opens and closes in a rictus of conflicted emotions.
Once again you find yourself in Ondra's waterlogged hall of power. The tired swaying of bioluminescent chandeliers casts uneven rays of light down on her court.

At the farthest end of the hall sits Ondra, as tall as a castle keep and leaning forward in her throne. She has adopted the head of an angler fish, and regards you with its globular stare. 

Her sickle-shaped jaw opens and closes in a rictus of conflicted emotions.

Pillars of coral and bone reach up to support a ceiling that must be hundreds of fathoms away. Chandeliers lit with bioluminescent globes dangle from long ropes, swaying in languid, tentacular motions.
Once again you find yourself in Ondra's waterlogged hall of power. The tired swaying of bioluminescent chandeliers casts uneven rays of light down on her court.

Her sickle-shaped jaw opens and closes in a rictus of conflicted emotions.
Once again you find yourself in Ondra's waterlogged hall of power. The tired swaying of bioluminescent chandeliers casts uneven rays of light down on her court.

You stand in a grand hall, underwater and cloaked in oppressive shadows. 

Pillars of coral and bone reach up to support a ceiling that must be hundreds of fathoms away. Chandeliers lit with bioluminescent globes dangle from long ropes, swaying in languid, tentacular motions.

At the farthest end of the hall sits Ondra, as tall as a castle keep and leaning forward in her throne. She has adopted the head of an angler fish, and regards you with its globular stare. 

Her sickle-shaped jaw opens and closes in a rictus of conflicted emotions.
Once again you find yourself in Ondra's waterlogged hall of power. The tired swaying of bioluminescent chandeliers casts uneven rays of light down on her court.
"I've heard enough."
"Ekera. So be it." Tekēhu sighs and looks off to the distance.

"Losing Ukaizo severed our connection to the gods. Over time, their gifts diminished."

The angler fish turns belly-up and puffs into vapor.
"You mean the one people would play with?"

"Anyone with the strength to pick me up may play with me, friend Xoti." 

Tekēhu winks at her.
"I'm the lord of Caed Nua, but you don't see me rebuilding my keep."
Entries.female: "I'm the lady of Caed Nua, but you don't see me rebuilding my keep."

Entries.default: "Ekera. Just so." The side of his mouth twitches.
"Well, you've certainly made up for lost time."
"Mine won't shut up."
He raises a hand to his lips and stifles laughter, shaking his head.
"To be worshipped, to have others interpret your design..." Tekēhu sighs, pulling back his hair.
"Such a burden. And mortals demand it so."
"It is not fair, I say."
"For what should a god worry about such cares, when theirs is the hand on the tiller?" Tekēhu spreads his palms and frowns.
"Maybe they worry because their hand is on the tiller."
"Are we still talking about Eothas?"
"Thanks for talking, Tekēhu."
He pauses, blinking at you with a handful of hair pressed between his fingers.
"Ekera, I... did not wish to burden you. These days I am having to think harder than my pampered years."
"Then maybe they did not always doubt themselves? At some time, they felt certain." Tekēhu nods to himself and bites his lower lip.
"Wouldn't you worry if you were in their position?"
"The gods... grow. They are like the adra holding Eora in place, I say - moving too slow for mortal eyes."
"You will forgive the handsome fish if he is as curious as the green god." He rubs the back of his neck and chuckles.
"Were I a god? Ekera, such a question."
"The tribes brought me this far. Is it... must I not also shoulder their burden as they did mine?"
"My heart is full, but I do not share it with the world lightly. Maybe in time..."
He cups his cheek and looks off to the distance, musing over his words.
"Enough of this."
"Ekera, thank you." His eyelashes flutter in momentary surprise.

"I say it is obvious now that Ngati brought me into the world to do this for the Huana."

He frowns, uncertain about his comfort with the idea.
"Ekera, but sometimes I wonder if we lost the covenant for a reason. And... if Ngati's chosen should choose his own path." Tekēhu sighs.
"It's a good thing we know where Ukaizo is."
"However it turns out, whatever we find... At least I have a good captain at my side." Tekēhu inclines his head.
"Our legends speak of the covenant with Ngati. One that defined the tribes for generations."

"Captain, I... I say I am without words."

Tekēhu clutches his shoulders tightly and looks away.

"Ngati brought me into the world as an omen, a bringer of change. 

"Serving on your crew has made me a bringer of death."
"I'm sorry. Onekaza needed to die."
"Change, death. It's all the same to me."
[Say nothing.]

"I say I was meant to change the Huana through art, through song and sculpture..."

Tekēhu leans back and closes his eyes.
"Leave me to my thoughts, captain. From now on, they are mine alone." Tekēhu smooths back his hair and pointedly refuses to make eye contact.
"Aruihi provoked this. I don't need to defend myself."

"Trouble me no more, captain. This pain... my heart is as a sea urchin now. 

"I am not the Tekēhu you knew." 

He lifts his eyes to meet yours for only a passing glance.
"I had some questions."
"Let's be off."
"No more questions, I say. Can we simply... leave?"
"Are you going to be okay?"

"From the slightest irritation a pearl is born."

Tekēhu brings his palm up to wipe his brow.
"I cannot say what will be born of this feeling, captain. It is beyond my knowing."
"The guild... for what did you do this, captain?"
Tekēhu merely shakes his head and stares down at his feet wearing a haunted expression.
"What say, shall we find him, captain?" Tekēhu nods, his brow furrowed.
"You get around, but I know you haven't done this before."

"Captain, I am my mother's son. I have seen things you would not believe." 

He folds his arms and winks.
"Let's be off."
